Activity Name: Harmoni: Towards Inclusion and Resilience Activity
Description: The Harmoni project addresses violent extremism by increasing the resilience of communities at risk; institutions known to be vulnerable (schools and universities); and population groups such as returnees who joined (or tried to join) ISIS, radicalized prisoners, and Indonesian labor migrants. Intolerance is increasing in Indonesia, including a growing acceptance of violent behavior and ideology. Social norms are changing and Indonesians are increasingly reluctant to speak publicly against intolerance. Politicians are increasingly using ultra-conservative religious symbols and divisive and exclusionary language. This activity strengthens the ability of community members and institutions to resist and reverse the influences of intolerance and extremism through early warning systems and grassroots mobilization.  For example, educational institutions will enhance risk assessments, oversight tools and processes, and improve guidelines for equity and inclusion. Students will gain critical thinking and soft skills to resist extremist messaging. Parole officers and social workers will develop processes and tools to effectively identify threats and more safely reintegrate former extremists. Improving the capacity of Indonesia to effectively address violent extremism threats and improve racial and religious tolerance supports regional and global security priorities.

Activity Name: Adolescent Girls' Education in Somalia (AGES) project
Description: The AGES project will work with communities, private providers, education ministries and religious leaders to improve literacy, numeracy and key life skills (financial literacy and knowledge of sexual and reproductive health) for up to 42,000 of the most marginalised girls in Somalia. The project will target the hardest to reach, out-of-school girls. It will focus on girls engaged in child labour, married and divorced girls, internally displaced persons, girls from minority clans and excluded groups, and pastoralists. Many of these girls have never attended school. The project will use a combination of formal and alternative education pathways to provide flexible learning options for girls who face multiple barriers to effective learning. It will work with girls, families, communities, schools and governments to promote lasting change in education.
